title: Gods and Monsters
author: Alan Barnes & Mike Maddox
filename: 164 - Gods and Monsters - Alan Barnes & Mike Maddox_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
REPRISE FROM ‘BLACK AND WHITE’:
INT. FENRIC’S KEEP — HALL
(FX: A MASSIVE VIKING-STYLE HALL ON A FLAT WORLD. A HELLISH HORN
BLOWS IN THE DISTANCE; ANSWERED BY OTHER, MORE DISTANT HORNS.
CRACKLE OF FIRE.)

(FX: TWISTING IN CHAINS) (DELIRIOUS) Black TARDIS — White TARDIS. Black pawn takes white queen’s bishop. White rook to- No! Black rook... No, white rook. White. White rabbit. Black cat. Cat takes rabbit. No, no, no. (CALMER) Get a grip, Doctor. Black — white — black — white. Queen takes King’s knight. Checkmate! (BEAT) I said, checkmate!
FX: A LOW CHUCKLE, OFF. SOMEONE APPROACHES...
But wait. Wait. (BEAT, UNSURE) Was I black? Or was I white? (DISTRAUGHT) Which side was I playing?
FX: THE SOMEONE STOPS. SOFT, EVIL, LAUGH
So.. we play the game again.
SCENE CONTINUES:
SCENE 1: INT. FENRIC’S KEEP — HALL [CONTINUOUS]
Where am I? Where is this place?
My Keep.
(FX: TWISTING IN CHAINS) Ninth century Scandinavian, from what I can see of the décor. (SEEING FENRIC) Ah, and your get-up.
The warlord whose body I wear would have called this world ‘Asgard’. But you may call it ‘Hell’.
There’s no such place.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 3
We shall see.
Play your games if you must. (BRIGHTLY) How about hide and seek? Off you pop, I’1ll be along ina bit.
You know the game I like to play. Don’t you? Time Lord.
(GRIMLY) Chess.
The game of gods. The pawns are assembled, the rooks and knights and bishops in formation.
I beat you once. I’m in no mood for a rematch.
You have no choice, Time Lord. Your TARDIS has just arrived in this domain. Your little friends, come to your rescue. Oh, what a game this will be!
(GROANING) Of course. They must have found the shield.
(EXCITED) The shield? Weyland’s Shield?
Following Weyland’s Shield is what dragged me into this game of yours. I should have known better.

Oh, but this is perfect! Weyland’s Shield, full of fire and magic. Weyland’s Shield, that will give me the power to realise my true potential! And your friends, Doctor, have delivered it right into my hands!
(TO SELF) Ohh, what have I done-?
At last, I shall make my true form manifest! And let the chains
of Fenric shatter!
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 4
SCENE 2: EXT. PLAIN — BY STREAM
(FX: SOUND OF WIND BLOWING. GENTLE TRICKLE OF STREAM, OFF. TARDIS
RATTLES OPEN)
(EXITING) Red sky at night. Nice. (CALLING BACK) Clear!
(EXITING) Give the ‘Who Dares Wins’ stuff a rest, Lysandra.
(EXITING) Why’s the sky that colour? Should the sky even be that colour?
(CALLING BACK) Hex! What’s keeping you?
(EXITING, HEFTING SAXON SHIELD) Figured if the Doctor went to all those lengths to get hold of Weyland’s Shield, makes sense to bring it with us.
It’s just dead weight, Hex.
(FX: CLOSES DOOR) Says the woman with a rucksack full of explosives.
SNIGGERS
Oi!
(LOOKING AROUND) Hold up. Are we on Mars?
I’ve been to Mars, Hex. Trust me, this isn’t Mars.
(FX: SLIGHTLY OFF, BY STREAM) Look, there’s a stream.
(FX: FOLLOW HIM AS HE CROSSES TO ARISTIDES) Do you not get streams on Mars?
Depends when on Mars.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 5
(COMING UP BESIDE) Ace is right. This isn’t Mars.
(COMING UP BESIDE) See, even Private Benjamin knows this isn’t — [Mars] (BREAKS OFF, TO SALLY) Hang about, how do you know this isn’t Mars?
I went to Mars. With the Doctor. He wanted to check up on some old hieroglyphics, in the tomb of an ancient star-god. (TO ARISTIDES) Captain, this isn’t Mars.
Fine, so it isn’t [Mars!]
FX: CUTTING OVER, SOFT HUM FROM SHIELD
(PULLED GENTLY BY SHIELD) Whoa!
Hex? This is no time to do your Pilates.
The shield. It, like, pulled me! (FX: HUM — PULLED AGAIN) Aah!
Captain, the shield! The runes on the shield — they’re glowing!
See, what’d I tell you?
The shield gave the TARDIS the co-ordinates for here, wherever
here is.
So?
So, I reckon it knows where it wants to go.
You mean, we should follow it?
FX: HUM
Downstream. It wants to go downstream.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 6
Guess downstream it is, then.
Come on.
FX: THE FOUR OF THEM STEPPING INTO STREAM, WALKING AWAY. FADE
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 7
SCENE 3: INT. FENRIC’S KEEP — HALL
FX: AS BEFORE. BLARE OF HORNS, OFF
Ah. There is movement on the board. I sense... yes! The scent of a she-wolf. One of my own.
Ace.
And a number of other... pieces. Why.. I think I know who they are!
Leave them alone. (FX: RATTLING CHAINS) I mean it, Fenric! Leave them alone, and play me!
Chess, Doctor. The pieces are... fair game.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL)
SCENE 4: EXT. PLAIN — BY STREAM)
Page 8
(FX: TRICKLE OF STREAM. SOFT HUM OF SHIELD LEADING HEX, SALLY,
ARISTIDES AND ACE THROUGH STREAM)
STOPPING) Hold up. (ALL STOP
What’s the matter? Hex?
The water. It’s turned red.
He’s right.
Must be a reflection from the sky. A trick of the light.
(SEEING BODIES IN WATER AHEAD) Don’t think so, Ace. Look!
Is that a body?
Bodies plural, Private.
Plural-?
Alright, everyone stay calm!
No-one’s panicking, Lysandra.
Speak for yourself, Ace.
FX: ALL MOVE A FEW FEET THROUGH WATER
(WALKING) They look like Vikings.
(WALKING) Saxons.
(WALKING) Same difference. (FX: ALL STOP) Schofield, you’re
medic. What killed them?
the
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 9
(SARCASTIC) I’m just guessing, but maybe having their throats torn out-—?
Yes, but what did it? Knives, swords, what-?
(EXAMINING BODY) Teeth and claws, it looks like.
Wild animals, then?
(SLIGHTLY OFF) No. Over here.
FX: 3 x SPLASHING STEPS OVER TO:
What’s that you’ve found, Morgan?
Fella here was packing a GPMG.
Looks like a machine gun.
General Purpose Machine Gun, yes.
There’s spent cartridges all over. What sort of wild animal couldn’t they fight off with a machine gun?
More to the point, Saxons with machine guns? This place is weird.
(FX: PICKING GUN OUT OF WATER) It gets weirder.
What’s that?
I dunno. Some kind of — (BEAT) — space gun.
Mate, is that the best you can come up with?
Well, how should I know what sort of gun it is?
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 10
Looks simple enough. A child could use it. So try it, Schofield.
Eh-?
What’s so hard? Point it, squeeze the trigger, ruin someone’s day.
Yeah, alright, Captain. (BEAT) No, doesn’t work.
(FX: SPLASHES OVER TO HEX) Like this. Point, squeeze and — (FX: BER-WHUMP FROM ALIEN GUN) See? Easy.
I’m telling you, it wouldn’t work for me!
(PASSING GUN) Morgan, show him.
Stand back. (SHOOTS)
FX: BER-WHUMP
There you go.
Well, why wouldn’t it work for me, then-?
It’s alien tech, maybe it won’t work for —
(WITHERINGLY) Humans?
. Men. Males. Ace, you try it.
Oi, you calling me a bloke?
Just do it, Ace.
FX: ACE SHOOTS. BER-WHUMP
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 11
OK. So maybe Private Benjamin’s onto something.
The only thing is — if it doesn’t work for males, why was a man holding it?
Maybe that’s why he’s dead?
The headline is, three of us can use it. And there’s all sorts lying around, so —
. Let’s tool up, shall we, ladies?
FX: ACE, ARISTIDES AND SALLY TOOL UP THROUGH:
Ace. The Doctor doesn’t like guns.

Didn’t like guns, Hex. These days, seems he’s quite comfortable hanging out with people who do. (HOISTING GPMG) So if we can’t beat, them — (FX: KA-CHUNK OF SAFETY CATCH) — guess we’re just going to have to join them, right?
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 5: INT. FENRIC’S KEEP — HALL
FX: AS BEFORE
(MURMURED, SENDING PSYCHIC MESSAGE) Ancient One. Come to me.
Do you know what it is I don’t understand about you, Fenric? You and the rest of the Elder Gods?
(IRRITATED) Oh, do enlighten me, Doctor.

. Still, after countless years in the outer darkness, still all you can think of to do with yourselves is play your stupid games. In all these endless millennia, haven’t you once thought of anything better to do with your time?
You are too small, your mind is too narrow.
But what’s the point?
Poor Doctor. Your mortal realm of stars and planets and people — you really believe that it matters.
Of course it matters!
These games of gods are reality, Doctor. They are all there is. They are the point.
FX: DOOR CREAKS OPEN, OFF
(ENTERING; VOICE GUTTURAL AND SAD, AS PER ‘CURSE OF FENRIC’ — BUT WITH THE FAINTEST POSSIBLE HINT OF HIS PERSIAN ORIGINS) Fenric. You bade me come.
Ah, Ancient One. There are strangers, out on the plain. Bring them to me.
I.. must obey.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 13
You must. Yes.
Then... I shall summon the Haemovores. (FX: EXITS)
(FX: TWISTING IN CHAINS) No!!!
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 14
SCENE 6: EXT. RIVER’S EDGE
(FX: FADE UP STREAM, WIDENING TO RIVER. 4 X PEOPLE TRAMPING ON:
& SALLY AHEAD; BUT WE’RE WITH ACE & ARISTIDES, LAGGING BEHIND)
. SO anyway, after I blew the school cupboard up, I bunked off school and went home. There was nothing to do, so I ended up watching kids’ TV. Jimbo and the Jet Set.
Oh. I loved that. The little planes!
Well funny, wasn’t it? You’1ll watch anything when there’s nothing on.
No, I meant I used to love it as a child.
It was only a couple of years ago.
Something like that.
(STOPPING, REALISATION) Ace, I was four.
But — you’re old enough to be my Mum!
Actually, you’re old enough to be [mine. ]
(FX: RETURNING FROM OFF, FOLLOWED BY HEX) Back! Back!
Hold up, the other two have seen something.
What is it, Private?
Column of soldiers. Over the ridge, in the far distance.
Yeah, headed back the way we came.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 15
What sort of soldiers?
I couldn’t see clearly in the mist.
Mist?
Yeah, rolling in from the east.
I saw them. All dressed up like refugees from Aladdin. Scimitars and that.
We should talk to them.
FX: SHIELD HUM
(IGNORING HER) What’s the shield say, Schofield?
Guess it wants us to carry on.
Then we carry on.
Lysandra. They might know something-!
Or they might just cut us to ribbons. The Captain’s right.
Unlike you, Private, she’s not the boss of me. (HOISTING BACKPACK) Look, I’1l catch you up, alright?
Ace, what are you playing at-?
(JOGGING OFF) I’1l be five minutes. Ten minutes. Ish!
(CALLING AFTER) Ace. Ace!!! (TO SALLY) Too late. She’s won’t see nothing in that mist.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 16
Ace can look after herself.
Thinks she can, Sal. Big difference.
FX: CROSS TO:
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 17
SCENE 7: EXT. RAVINE
FX: FADE UP ACE SCRAMBLING DOWN RIDGE
(MUTTERING TO SELF) .. Yes, Captain. No, Captain. Would you like your boots blacked, Captain? (BEAT) Right, then. North-west, I guess. Pff, she wasn’t wrong about this [mist-!]
(FROM OFF) Drop your weapon, warrior woman.
(TO SELF) Walked straight into that, didn’t I-?
(FX: FROM OFF, BER-WHUMP OF ALIEN GUN, AS BEFORE. SHOWER OF ROCKS,
CRIES OUT, HIT BY STONES
(OFF) I said, drop your weapon!
(LOUD) Alright, alright! (FX: SETS GPMG ON GROUND; SIMULTANEOUSLY,
SCRAMBLES DOWN RIDGE, TOWARDS ACE) Consider it dropped. Not my bag, anyhow.
(APPROACHING) This is not your bag? On your back?
What, the rucksack? No, that’s mine. I meant the whole ‘guns’ thing.
(WITH HER) What kind of creature are you-?
My name’s Ace, I’m from a dysfunctional family, and I cope by blowing things up. What’s your excuse... Aladdin?
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 18
SCENE 8: INT. FENRIC’S KEEP — HALL
FX: AS BEFORE
So, Fenric, you’ve found yourself a new Ancient One. You do realise how absurd that sounds?
You mock and sneer, because you are scared.
Of course I’m scared! You’re quite insane and quite ridiculously powerful. That thing, the Ancient One. What corrupted future did you dredge him up from?

I told you. We are in Hell. Your future, your present, your past — your Time is meaningless, Time Lord. Look out of my Keep, and all you will see is a sky of red; red because the stars in the newborn sky are all so close together that there is neither day or night.
What do you mean, newborn? How far back are we?

To me, Doctor, your universe is less than a millionth of a second old. In the blink of my undying eye, it will be a burst bubble. All of your future, all of your past, the whole of your reality — we Elder Gods perceive it as no more than you perceive a single speck of dust. To us, your everything is nothing. There is nothing here... but us.
If we mortals are really nothing, why bother with us at all? Why not just leave us all alone?
And what do you think would happen if we did?
Nothing, by your reckoning!
Precisely, Doctor. Nothing would happen. Simply, nothing. There would be only nothing. And that isn’t anything, is it?
You need us, don’t you? You need our universe to be the something to your nothing. You need us to give you scale!
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 19
Perhaps.
Oh, but don’t you see, Fenric? We mortal nothings can happily live without you, but your lives are meaningless without ours. That makes us greater than you!
(ANNOYED; MORE TO SELF) Can it be? That I’m debating philosophy with a speck of dust, when there’s a game to be played?
(FX: ‘WIND’ WHIPS UP — AND FENRIC TELEPORTS AWAY, AS IN ‘CURSE OF FENRIC’ )
(ALOUD) Go on, then, disappear! Just as soon as you’re losing the argument!
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 20
SCENE 9: EXT. RAVINE
My name is not Aladdin, warrior woman. I am Hurmzid, Prince of Persia. I am looking for my guards. We became separated, in the mist.
Yeah, well — they went that-a-way.
That-a-way?
(FX: HOISTING BACKPACK) C’mon, follow me.
But - you are my prisoner!
Look, Hurmzid, Prince of Persia — do you want to find your guards or not?
I do.
Well, then — let’s find them, shall we?
FX: THEY WALK
(WALKING) You know what lies this way, warrior woman?
(WALKING) Ace. And all that lies this way is a load of dead Saxons. Come to think of it — you’re from a different time period, aren’t you?
(WALKING) ‘Time... period’?
(WALKING) Age. Epoch. (SIGHS) Just give us some names of people and places, recent events?
(WALKING) My father is the Emperor Shapur. He defeated the Roman army at the battle of Edessa and took their emperor prisoner.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 21
Never heard of him. (STOPS; SUDDENLY SINKING IN) Sorry, did you say he beat the Romans?
Yes.
Respect.
(WALKING) The Romans were cut off without reinforcements, struck down by a mystery plague.
(WALKING) What sort of plague?
(WALKING) My father made a deal with an ancient spirit. A djinni. He gave him a magic potion called “Anthrax”.
(WALKING) That’s disgusting.

(WALKING) In return for this help, the spirit took my father away, and he has not been seen since. But then I heard the djinni had again been sighted, playing dice on the road to Byzantium. So I sneaked into the demon’s tent, and stole a talisman imbued with all his power.
What sort of talisman?
(STOPPING) Here, I keep it around my belt.
It’s a hammer. A little hammer.
It has an enchantment upon it. It conjures up a powerful spell called a “time storm”, that brought [me and my guards]
(SUDDENLY SCARED) Did you say —
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 22

A time storm, yes. It brought me and my guards here, to this plain of mists and monsters. (SADLY) I wished then that I had heeded the advice of the strange little Doctor I had met on the high road, who warned me never to tangle with demons [and devils —]
Right. Gonna stop you there, Hurmzid, because we’ve suddenly got way more in common than you can possibly imagine —
(FX: CUT SHORT BY A ZOMBIE-LIKE GROANING FROM AHEAD; A MASS OF
APPROACHING )
Hang about. What was that you said about monsters-?
They are coming! The monsters are coming!
Please. Tell me these monsters of yours aren’t mostly a mouldy blue colour, and in urgent need of a manicure?
(DESPERATE) My guards! What has happened to my guards?
Too late for them, Hurmzid. (FX: APPROACHING HAEMOVORES PAUSE)
That lot, they’re called Haemovores. They got the name from drinking blood.
Drinking... blood?
FX: HAEMOVORE MOANS, SURGING FORWARD
Don’t just stand there, your Highness — run!!!
FX: THEY RUN, PURSUED BY HAEMOVORES
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 10: EXT. RIVER’S EDGE/WORLD’S EDGE
FX: THE RIVER WIDENING OUT. SOUND OF WATERFALL AHEAD
(WALKING) Ace should have been back by now.
(WALKING) Let’s just push on, shall we?
(STOPPING) Hold up.
What is it, Private?
Up ahead. It sounds like a waterfall.
Looks more like a lake.
Something’s not right. Look, I won’t be a moment. (FX: DASHES OFF)
Private! Private Morgan! Come back!
Trouble in the ranks, Lysandra?
Follow me, Schofield.
(FX: SHE RUSHES AFTER SALLY. CROSS TO THE EDGE OF THE LAKE. WATER
OFF THE EDGE... BUT INTO NOTHING, EMPTY SPACE)
(FX: RUSHES TO SUDDEN STOP) Aaah!
(APPROACHING FROM OFF) I gave you an order, Private..!
(CALLING) Stop! Captain, stop! Don’t go near the water!
(OFF, STOPPED) What-?
It’s not a waterfall!
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 24
(OFF) Well, what is it? Sal?
It’s the edge! Come round the outside, you’ll see!
(APPROACHING FROM OFF) The edge of what?
(PERHAPS TO SELF?) It’s incredible. Like nothing I’ve ever seen...
(FX: ARRIVING, WITH HEX) What are you on about, Pri- [-vate?] (REALISATION) Oh my stars.
See? The edge. The edge of the world!
(TRYING TO MAKE SENSE OF IT) We followed a river.
Yes, and look! It just runs straight off, into... well —
. Space.
Space, exactly!
What is this place-?
Whatever it is, it’s flat. This world is flat!
Yes, and we nearly walked off the edge of it!
FX: IN FAR DISTANCE — ACE, RUNNING TOWARDS THEM, WITH HURMZID
(WELL OFF, RUNNING, CALLING) Hex! Run!!!
Hold up, there’s Ace!
(WELL OFF, RUNNING, CALLING) Leg it! Run!!!
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 25
What’s she saying?
Yes, and who’s that with her?
(BY ACE) The monsters are almost upon us!!!
Looks like one of them Arabian Nights guys. (CALLING) Over here!!!
They’re running. What are they running from?
(FX: CROSS TO ACE & HURMZID. BEHIND THEM — HAEMOVORES SURGING FORWARD, GROANING)
(RUNNING) The stars preserve us!
(RUNNING, CALLING) Hex! Sal! Lysandra! Don’t just sit there like lemons! Run!!!
FX: CROSS BACK TO:
There’s people behind them, in the mist.
Maybe it’s the rest of that column. Be just like McShane to anatagonise them.
No, it’s not them.
How can you tell? From this distance?

Well — me eyesight’s not perfect, but I’m pretty sure they weren’t blue. Not that I’m saying that blue’s bad necessarily. I mean, you travel with the Doctor, you soon learn that appearances aren’t everything. People who might look scary sometimes turn out to be (HESITANTLY) quite (LESS SURE) friendly. Are those suckers?
Captain, you were wondering what killed those Saxons...
I think we just found out.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 26
(RUNNING UP) Come on!!! You lot! What’re you all just standing around for?
(JUST BEHIND) The monsters are coming! Run!!!
Just one problem, McShane.
Oh, what? You feel like re-enacting Custard’s Last Stand, I suppose?
(CORRECTING HER) Custer’s Last Stand.
Shut it!
Thing is, Ace, there’s nowhere to run to.
Yeah, well — we don’t go in the water. (FX: CLAMBERING PAST THEM,
EDGE; THUNDERING WATERFALL) But we can always go around the outs- [ide —]
See?
Is that... space?
Flat planet.
Bad one.
FX: HAEMOVORES NEARLY UPON THEM; GROANING
No way forward, no way back, mist rolling in from the east and
the west. (GRIM) Looks like Custard’s Last Stand it is.
FX: CROSS DIRECTLY TO:
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL)
SCENE 11: EXT. RIVER’S EDGE [CONTINUOUS]
FX: HAEMOVORES SHAMBLE-STOP AT WATER’S EDGE. MOANING
Beware the water, my brothers. It
is not safe in the water. There
are.. undercurrents, that will drag you from the plain.
FX: HAEMOVORES GROAN FEARFULLY
MATERIALISES — FX AS BEFORE
Hush. Our master arrives.
Ancient One. How goes the game?
The pieces are on the far edge of
move forward, nor back.
(SCANNING THE EDGE) The shield. I
FX: CROSS DIRECTLY TO:
the board. They can neither
do not see the shield...
Page 27
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 28
SCENE 12: EXT. WORLD’S EDGE [CONTINUOUS]
FX: WATERFALL AS BEFORE
They’ve stopped moving. There’s a man, talking to the big blue Boss.
The Viking guy?
With these strange green eyes.
Fenric. Hoped I’d never live to see him again.
But — that is the djinni! The demon who took my father!
Sorry, who’s this?
His highness Prince Hurmzid. His Dad beat the Romans, so he’s probably a good bloke on your side in a fight, if he’s anything like his Dad.
Alright?
Hurmzid’s from Persia. He knew the Professor, once.
That’s quite a coincidence.
Oh no. No coincidence. You see, I first met the Professor on a planet called Iceworld. I’d been taken there by a time storm.
I, too, was carried away from my home.
So who’s this Fenric?
Scumbag from the dawn of time, according to the Professor.
The Doctor called someone a “scumbag?”
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 29
I’m painting a picture. Fenric played the Professor at chess,

only Fenric lost, and the Professor sealed him up inside a bottle. Trouble is, a few hundred years later, the bottle got stolen by a bunch of Vikings, who tried to take it back to Norway. The curse followed them, they were all turned into Haemovores.
Don’t tell me. The blue guys in the mist?
“Haemovores”. As in haemotologist, as in blood? Something that eats blood?
Vampires?
Pretty much.
Today just gets better and better.
FX: CROSS BACK TO:
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 13: EXT. RIVER’S EDGE [CONTINUOUS]
FX: HAEMOVORES GROANING
My brothers would feed, Lord Fenric.
No. No! The shieldmaidens protect the shield. And if the shield is lost, so too is the game. This is a fool’s mate, Ancient One!
Why do you call me that? This universe is young. There is nothing ancient here.
You were old when I summoned you, were you not? So numbed by your conquests that you welcomed the burn of Hell. (DECISIVELY) No, only a daring play will deliver me the shield. A change of tactics.
Then... make your move, my Lord.
FX: FENRIC WHIPPING UP HUGE TIME STORM THROUGH:
(EFFORT — BRINGING UP HUGE TIME STORM TO WHISK AWAY HIMSELF, AND THE HAEMOVORES) Castling. The King’s leap. The King exchanged... for his Keep!
(FX: TIME STORM SOUNDS AND HAEMOVORE GROANS CROSSFADE INTO HUGE
GRINDING... AND A THUNDEROUS CHUD! AS ALL DISAPPEAR IN THE STORM, FENRIC’S KEEP TAKING THEIR PLACE ON THE PLAIN. CROSS
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 31
SCENE 14: EXT. WORLD’S EDGE [CONTINUOUS]
FX: WATERFALL OFF
(FEARFUL) Look! Fenric’s Keep!
(ASTONISHMENT) Whoa! Where did that come from?
More to the point, where did the Haemovores go?
Time storm. Fenric’s playing games with us.
What did you call that, your Highness? Fenric’s Keep?
It is. But the last time I saw it, it was ten leagues to the east!
Hang about. That’s more than a Keep. That’s a rook.
What are you on about, Schofield?
A rook. A castle, in chess.
She’s right, Captain. It’s a chesspiece. A giant chesspiece!
But that’s impossible!
Lysandra. We’re standing on a flat world floating in space populated by zombie Vikings, and you call that impossible?
Fair point, McShane.
Fenric plays games, that’s his M.O. Chess, that’s his favourite. Anyone here play chess? (SHORT BEAT) Oh well, worth a [try —]
I used to play a bit. You know, after school. Chess club.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 32
Well, well. Aren’t you the dark horse, Morgan?
(BLUSHING) I wasn’t very good, or anything. Well, I was the district champion two years running, but the competition wasn’t all that [strong]

HURMZID: (WALKING) In return for this help, the spirit took my father away, and he has not been seen since. But then I heard the djinni had again been sighted, playing dice on the road to Byzantium. So I sneaked into the demon’s tent, and stole a talisman imbued with all his power.
ACE: What sort of talisman?
HURMZID: (STOPPING) Here, I keep it around my belt.
ACE: It’s a hammer. A little hammer.
HURMZID: It has an enchantment upon it. It conjures up a powerful spell called a “time storm”, that brought [me and my guards]
ACE: (SUDDENLY SCARED) Did you say —
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 22
HURMZID: A time storm, yes. It brought me and my guards here, to this plain of mists and monsters. (SADLY) I wished then that I had heeded the advice of the strange little Doctor I had met on the high road, who warned me never to tangle with demons [and devils —]
ACE: Right. Gonna stop you there, Hurmzid, because we’ve suddenly got way more in common than you can possibly imagine —
ACE: (FX: CUT SHORT BY A ZOMBIE-LIKE GROANING FROM AHEAD; A MASS OF
HAEMOVORES: APPROACHING )
ACE: Hang about. What was that you said about monsters-?
HURMZID: They are coming! The monsters are coming!
ACE: Please. Tell me these monsters of yours aren’t mostly a mouldy blue colour, and in urgent need of a manicure?
HURMZID: (DESPERATE) My guards! What has happened to my guards?
ACE: Too late for them, Hurmzid. (FX: APPROACHING HAEMOVORES PAUSE)
ACE: That lot, they’re called Haemovores. They got the name from drinking blood.
HURMZID: Drinking... blood?
ACE: Don’t just stand there, your Highness — run!!!
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 23
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 10: EXT. RIVER’S EDGE/WORLD’S EDGE
HEX: (WALKING) Ace should have been back by now.
ARISTIDES: (WALKING) Let’s just push on, shall we?
SALLY: (STOPPING) Hold up.
ARISTIDES: What is it, Private?
SALLY: Up ahead. It sounds like a waterfall.
ARISTIDES: Looks more like a lake.
SALLY: Something’s not right. Look, I won’t be a moment. (FX: DASHES OFF)
ARISTIDES: Private! Private Morgan! Come back!
HEX: Trouble in the ranks, Lysandra?
ARISTIDES: Follow me, Schofield.
ARISTIDES: (FX: SHE RUSHES AFTER SALLY. CROSS TO THE EDGE OF THE LAKE. WATER
THUNDERING: OFF THE EDGE... BUT INTO NOTHING, EMPTY SPACE)
SALLY: (FX: RUSHES TO SUDDEN STOP) Aaah!
ARISTIDES: (APPROACHING FROM OFF) I gave you an order, Private..!
SALLY: (CALLING) Stop! Captain, stop! Don’t go near the water!
ARISTIDES: (OFF, STOPPED) What-?
SALLY: It’s not a waterfall!
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 24
HEX: (OFF) Well, what is it? Sal?
SALLY: It’s the edge! Come round the outside, you’ll see!
ARISTIDES: (APPROACHING FROM OFF) The edge of what?
SALLY: (PERHAPS TO SELF?) It’s incredible. Like nothing I’ve ever seen...
ARISTIDES: (FX: ARRIVING, WITH HEX) What are you on about, Pri- [-vate?] (REALISATION) Oh my stars.
SALLY: See? The edge. The edge of the world!
ARISTIDES: (TRYING TO MAKE SENSE OF IT) We followed a river.
SALLY: Yes, and look! It just runs straight off, into... well —
HEX: . Space.
SALLY: Space, exactly!
ARISTIDES: What is this place-?
HEX: Whatever it is, it’s flat. This world is flat!
SALLY: Yes, and we nearly walked off the edge of it!
ACE: (WELL OFF, RUNNING, CALLING) Hex! Run!!!
HEX: Hold up, there’s Ace!
ACE: (WELL OFF, RUNNING, CALLING) Leg it! Run!!!
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 25
ARISTIDES: What’s she saying?
SALLY: Yes, and who’s that with her?
HURMZID: (BY ACE) The monsters are almost upon us!!!
HEX: Looks like one of them Arabian Nights guys. (CALLING) Over here!!!
ARISTIDES: They’re running. What are they running from?
ARISTIDES: (FX: CROSS TO ACE & HURMZID. BEHIND THEM — HAEMOVORES SURGING FORWARD, GROANING)
HURMZID: (RUNNING) The stars preserve us!
ACE: (RUNNING, CALLING) Hex! Sal! Lysandra! Don’t just sit there like lemons! Run!!!
SALLY: There’s people behind them, in the mist.
ARISTIDES: Maybe it’s the rest of that column. Be just like McShane to anatagonise them.
HEX: No, it’s not them.
ARISTIDES: How can you tell? From this distance?
HEX: Well — me eyesight’s not perfect, but I’m pretty sure they weren’t blue. Not that I’m saying that blue’s bad necessarily. I mean, you travel with the Doctor, you soon learn that appearances aren’t everything. People who might look scary sometimes turn out to be (HESITANTLY) quite (LESS SURE) friendly. Are those suckers?
SALLY: Captain, you were wondering what killed those Saxons...
ARISTIDES: I think we just found out.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 26
ACE: (RUNNING UP) Come on!!! You lot! What’re you all just standing around for?
HURMZID: (JUST BEHIND) The monsters are coming! Run!!!
ARISTIDES: Just one problem, McShane.
ACE: Oh, what? You feel like re-enacting Custard’s Last Stand, I suppose?
SALLY: (CORRECTING HER) Custer’s Last Stand.
ACE: Shut it!
HEX: Thing is, Ace, there’s nowhere to run to.
ACE: Yeah, well — we don’t go in the water. (FX: CLAMBERING PAST THEM,
TOWARDS: EDGE; THUNDERING WATERFALL) But we can always go around the outs- [ide —]
ARISTIDES: See?
ACE: Is that... space?
HEX: Flat planet.
ACE: Bad one.
ARISTIDES: No way forward, no way back, mist rolling in from the east and
ARISTIDES: the west. (GRIM) Looks like Custard’s Last Stand it is.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL)
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 11: EXT. RIVER’S EDGE [CONTINUOUS]
ANCIENT ONE: Beware the water, my brothers. It
ANCIENT ONE: is not safe in the water. There
ANCIENT ONE: are.. undercurrents, that will drag you from the plain.
ANCIENT ONE: Hush. Our master arrives.
FENRIC: Ancient One. How goes the game?
ANCIENT ONE: The pieces are on the far edge of
ANCIENT ONE: move forward, nor back.
FENRIC: (SCANNING THE EDGE) The shield. I
FENRIC: the board. They can neither
FENRIC: do not see the shield...
FENRIC: Page 27
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 28
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 12: EXT. WORLD’S EDGE [CONTINUOUS]
SALLY: They’ve stopped moving. There’s a man, talking to the big blue Boss.
HEX: The Viking guy?
SALLY: With these strange green eyes.
ACE: Fenric. Hoped I’d never live to see him again.
HURMZID: But — that is the djinni! The demon who took my father!
ARISTIDES: Sorry, who’s this?
ACE: His highness Prince Hurmzid. His Dad beat the Romans, so he’s probably a good bloke on your side in a fight, if he’s anything like his Dad.
HEX: Alright?
ACE: Hurmzid’s from Persia. He knew the Professor, once.
ARISTIDES: That’s quite a coincidence.
ACE: Oh no. No coincidence. You see, I first met the Professor on a planet called Iceworld. I’d been taken there by a time storm.
HURMZID: I, too, was carried away from my home.
SALLY: So who’s this Fenric?
ACE: Scumbag from the dawn of time, according to the Professor.
HEX: The Doctor called someone a “scumbag?”
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 29
ACE: I’m painting a picture. Fenric played the Professor at chess,
ACE: only Fenric lost, and the Professor sealed him up inside a bottle. Trouble is, a few hundred years later, the bottle got stolen by a bunch of Vikings, who tried to take it back to Norway. The curse followed them, they were all turned into Haemovores.
HEX: Don’t tell me. The blue guys in the mist?
ARISTIDES: “Haemovores”. As in haemotologist, as in blood? Something that eats blood?
SALLY: Vampires?
ACE: Pretty much.
HEX: Today just gets better and better.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 30
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 13: EXT. RIVER’S EDGE [CONTINUOUS]
ANCIENT ONE: My brothers would feed, Lord Fenric.
FENRIC: No. No! The shieldmaidens protect the shield. And if the shield is lost, so too is the game. This is a fool’s mate, Ancient One!
ANCIENT ONE: Why do you call me that? This universe is young. There is nothing ancient here.
FENRIC: You were old when I summoned you, were you not? So numbed by your conquests that you welcomed the burn of Hell. (DECISIVELY) No, only a daring play will deliver me the shield. A change of tactics.
ANCIENT ONE: Then... make your move, my Lord.
FENRIC: (EFFORT — BRINGING UP HUGE TIME STORM TO WHISK AWAY HIMSELF, AND THE HAEMOVORES) Castling. The King’s leap. The King exchanged... for his Keep!
FENRIC: (FX: TIME STORM SOUNDS AND HAEMOVORE GROANS CROSSFADE INTO HUGE
STONE: GRINDING... AND A THUNDEROUS CHUD! AS ALL DISAPPEAR IN THE STORM, FENRIC’S KEEP TAKING THEIR PLACE ON THE PLAIN. CROSS
DIRECTLY TO: )
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 31
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 14: EXT. WORLD’S EDGE [CONTINUOUS]
HURMZID: (FEARFUL) Look! Fenric’s Keep!
HEX: (ASTONISHMENT) Whoa! Where did that come from?
ARISTIDES: More to the point, where did the Haemovores go?
ACE: Time storm. Fenric’s playing games with us.
SALLY: What did you call that, your Highness? Fenric’s Keep?
HURMZID: It is. But the last time I saw it, it was ten leagues to the east!
HEX: Hang about. That’s more than a Keep. That’s a rook.
ARISTIDES: What are you on about, Schofield?
ACE: A rook. A castle, in chess.
SALLY: She’s right, Captain. It’s a chesspiece. A giant chesspiece!
ARISTIDES: But that’s impossible!
ACE: Lysandra. We’re standing on a flat world floating in space populated by zombie Vikings, and you call that impossible?
ARISTIDES: Fair point, McShane.
ACE: Fenric plays games, that’s his M.O. Chess, that’s his favourite. Anyone here play chess? (SHORT BEAT) Oh well, worth a [try —]
SALLY: I used to play a bit. You know, after school. Chess club.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 32
ARISTIDES: Well, well. Aren’t you the dark horse, Morgan?
SALLY: (BLUSHING) I wasn’t very good, or anything. Well, I was the district champion two years running, but the competition wasn’t all that [strong]
ACE: (BUTTING IN) A dark horse. (SUSPICIOUS) That’s a black knight, isn’t it?
SALLY: I suppose.
HEX: Hold on, Ace, what’re you saying?
ACE: I’m saying there’s no such thing as coincidence, not where Fenric’s concerned.
ARISTIDES: It was only a figure of speech, McShane. (CHANGING SUBJECT) Hurmzid — your Highness — what else do you know about this Keep?
HURMZID: The Keep is where Fenric holds my father. Where he holds all of his prisoners.
HEX: Prisoners? So what’s the betting that in the very next cel1l...?
SALLY: Captain, the Doctor’s in there! He must be!
ARISTIDES: Right then. Fenric’s made his move. That means it’s our turn.
HEX: You mean — attack the Keep? How?
ARISTIDES: These (COUGH) “space guns” seem to work well enough.
ACE: You want to watch it, Lysandra. Fenric, he’s like a Grandmaster. Which I guess makes us the Furious Five.
SALLY: What?
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 33
ACE: Eighties reference. You wouldn’t get it.
ARISTIDES: Alright, McShane. (TO ALL) We proceed with all due caution — agreed?
ARISTIDES: I’1ll take that as a ‘Yes, Captain’. Come on.
HURMZID: Ace. I made you drop your... “Space gun”.
ACE: (HOISTING RUCKSACK) Not to worry, your Highness. I’ve still got my rucksack.
HURMZID: But do you not feel fear?
ACE: Oh, I feel fear, alright. I know all about Fenric. But if Fenric’s got the Professor in there, then he’s the one who needs to be scared, because I know exactly how I’m getting the Professor out.
HURMZID: I wish I had your faith.
ACE: Yeah. A rucksack packed full of unshakeable faith. Go on, your Highness.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 34
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 15: INT. FENRIC’S KEEP — HALL
DOCTOR: (TWISTING IN CHAINS) Who’s that? Who’s there?
ANCIENT ONE: You have nothing to fear, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Ah, “Ancient One”. Listen, whatever Fenric’s threatened you with, whatever hold he has on you, I can help. I’ve fought him before. He can be contained.
ANCIENT ONE: In the earthly realm, perhaps. But not here, in the darkness before creation.
DOCTOR: All the same. Release me from these chains. Let me try. (BEAT; ANNOYED) What’s the matter, don’t you want me to save you?
ANCIENT ONE: You should know, Doctor — I am beyond salvation.
DOCTOR: I should know? Why should I know? (BEAT) Who are you, Ancient One? — or rather, who were you? Did I know you, once? Will I know you?
ANCIENT ONE: I am lost and forsaken. That is all. (TURNING, EXITING) You will remain here until Fenric decides your fate.
DOCTOR: (TO SELF) My fate? Fenric decided that a long time ago.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 35
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 16: EXT. FENRIC’S KEEP
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: RIVER’S EDGE OFF. ARISTIDES, SALLY, HEX, HURMZID AND ACE RUN UP TO GATE AND STOP)
ARISTIDES: (SOTTO) OK. Main gate — looks to be... (LOOKS) — wide open.
ACE: There’s no point in whispering, Lysandra. It’s obvious. He knows we're coming. He’s inviting us in.
HEX: What are those carvings of? On the gate?
ACE: Wolves.
ARISTIDES: Plan of attack, Morgan?
SALLY: We go in in a diamond formation. Fastest first — guess that’s me. Covering fire to the left and right — that’1l be you and McShane. Anyone tries to take us from behind, they’1ll be at close quarters — so that’s one for Hurmzid, and his scimitar.
ARISTIDES: Very good, Private.
HEX: Hey, what about me?
ARISTIDES: You — hold our coats, Schofield.
ACE: Here’s a better idea. As before, but Hurmzid stays behind with Hex.
HURMZID: But — what about my father?
ACE: We won’t leave without him. But the fact is — Hex can’t fire these weapons, for some reason. So someone needs to cover him.
HEX: I’m not completely useless.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 36
ACE: No-one said you were. (FX: THUMP OF BAG ON GROUND) Hurmzid — will you stay here, and look after my rucksack?
HURMZID: I will not argue.
ACE: Oh, I like you! Now — give me that space gun of yours.
ARISTIDES: What, it works for him?
ACE: Yeah, it does, actually.
HEX: I take it back. I am completely useless.
ACE: Trust me, someone might need a sticking plaster later. Oh! One more thing. Hurmzid — that hammer of yours...?
HURMZID: You would take my talisman, too?
ACE: Please. If your father’s in there — I will find him, I promise.
HURMZID: (PASSING IT) I believe I can trust you.
ACE: Just tell me how it works.
HURMZID: You strike the ground and think of where you wish to be.
ACE: Cool.
ARISTIDES: Are you quite ready?
ACE: Yeah. Sally, Lysandra — you’re back-up in case it goes wrong.
SALLY: In case what goes wrong?
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 37
ACE: This. (RUNS TO GATES, SHOUTS) Oi! Fenric! The name’s Ace. Remember me?
ARISTIDES: (HISSED AFTER HER) McShane! (TO SALLY) What the hell does she think she’s playing at?
SALLY: She’s already in. Better get after her, Ma’am.
ARISTIDES: Against my better judgement...
HEX: Look after yourselves, ladies.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 38
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 17: INT. FENRIC’S KEEP — COURTYARD [CONTINUOUS]
ACE: (FX: WALKING AROUND, CALLING OUT) I’m here! I’m all ready for you! So show yourself, dogbreath!
FENRIC: The child of the baby. Yes, I remember you.
ACE: See you’ve joined the Asterix Fan Club. (STORMING FORWARD) Where is he? Where’s the Doctor?
FENRIC: There are so many ways I could kill you. Aren’t you afraid?
ACE: Yeah, but I’ve not made my move yet. You know the rules, Fenric. First I make my move, then you make yours.
SALLY: (MOVING TO STOP) (SOTTO) He’s in range, Captain.
ARISTIDES: (SOTTO) Then let’s take him down.
SALLY: (SOTTO) Shoot him?
ARISTIDES: fire!!!
FENRIC: Ah. The shield maidens.
FENRIC: How... amusing. That was your move, I believe?
ACE: (TURNING) You idiots! You didn’t really think that guns would work on him, did you?
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 39
ARISTIDES: Well, you know. Space guns.
SALLY: “Shield maidens”. What did he mean, “shield maidens”?
FENRIC: If you prefer — the three witches. The maiden, the wife and the hag.
ARISTIDES: He’s calling you names, McShane.
FENRIC: The Norn. The three women at the heart of all the chaos to come. You are here at last, as I always knew you would be.
SALLY: Anyone know what he’s on about?
ACE: He’s completely hatstand. Just go with it.
SALLY: (CONFUSED) Hatstand?
ACE: Sorry. Eighties thing again.
ARISTIDES: (STEPPING FORWARD) What are you on about, Fenric? ‘The chaos to
ARISTIDES: come’ ?
FENRIC: Since you wish to be better informed — I summon a time storm!
ARISTIDES: & SALLY:
FENRIC: Best, perhaps, that you experience these things at first hand.
ACE: Hey! Leave them alone!
ARISTIDES: (CAUGHT IN STORM) Stop it!
SALLY: (DITTO) Ace! Help us —
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 40
ACE: Where have you sent them, Fenric?
FENRIC: To their deaths, of course. Theirs, and that of everyone else on the dismal planet Earth.
ACE: And what about me? Aren’t I included?
FENRIC: You, Dorothy McShane? You have your own personal hell to visit.
ACE: (IN TIME STORM) Go on, then. Do your [worst! —]
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 41
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 18: EXT. PERIVALE STREET [CONTINUOUS]
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: TIME STORM CRESCENDOES.. AND IS REPLACED WITH DISTANT CARS; A
TUBE: TRAIN; BIRDSONG)
ACE: (DAZED) Where am I-?
FENRIC: I told you, Dorothy McShane.
ACE: Came along for the ride, did you? (GETTING UP) So bright, I can’t see a thing.
FENRIC: Let me help you gain your bearings. We are on a hill, an island of green surrounded by tarmac. In front of us lie Jubilee Road and George the Fifth Way. Over there, traffic is backed up all the way along the Western Avenue, from Hanger Lane to the Hoover Factory.
ACE: (HORRIFIED) This is Perivale...!
FENRIC: Welcome home, Dorothy McShane. Welcome... to hell!
FENRIC: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 42

elements.text: PART TWO
(HORRIFIED) This is Perivale...!
Welcome home, Dorothy McShane. Welcome... to hell!
CONTINUES INTO:
SCENE 19: EXT. PERIVALE STREET [CONTINUOUS]
What’s your game, Fenric?
It is an unseasonably sticky afternoon in the early summer of 1987. This time tomorrow, a time storm will transport the younger you from here to Iceworld, where you will first encounter the Doctor.
So-?

So.. you can stop the younger you from leaving, should you choose. Some other tortured soul can take her place as my agent in the TARDIS. It was always a toss-up between you and a lovelorn young motorcyclist in.. Wales, if I remember right?
Oh, you’re a piece of work, you are.

Your life might have been so very different, Dorothy McShane. Stop the younger you from entering the time storm, and let her enjoy a life free from my taint. You never know, she might even be pushing a pram by this time next year. Alone and unloved. Just like her mother.
What makes you so sure I won’t choose the baby buggy?
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 43

Why — because then you’d be giving up on the Doctor. And we both know — you won’t ever do that, will you? No. I’d sooner let you become a ghost of the timeline, watching on from the shadows. Watching yourself become old and used-up and beaten-down, and knowing that you could have prevented it.
Yeah, you’d love that, wouldn’t you?
(BRIGHTLY) I could always come for your daughter, in some nearby council estate in, what, eighteen years’ time? That might be... intriguing.
The Professor would say there’s worse than Perivale. Worse than here. (LOOKING AROUND) Perhaps he’s right. This isn’t Hell.

No, it isn’t. Your hell is knowing I made you everything you are, Dorothy McShane. Your hell is knowing you won’t choose to save your younger self. Your hell is knowing you can’t help yourself from choosing me!
Why me, Fenric? Why couldn’t you leave me alone?

Stupid child, I told you. I didn’t choose you. Just the toss of a coin. Odds, evens, black, white — it’s all in the game. But whichever way the penny drops, whichever way the cards fold — I win. I always win.
(FALSE BROKEN) Yeah. Yeah, I know. You win, Fenric. You win... (PULLING OUT HURMZID’S HAMMER; EXULTANT) .. the wooden spoon!
That’s not a spoon, that’s a — [hammer] (REALISATION) That is my
hammer! Where did you [get that-?]
FX: ACE BASHES HAMMER ON TARMAC. LIGHTNING SOUND

Hurmzid, Prince of Persia. (FX: TIME STORM WHIPS UP) (TO SELF) Oh! I meant to say — ah, never mind, near enough. (TO FENRIC) Enjoy Perivale, scumbag. (FX: FADING AWAY — INTO SCENE 21) [If you’re hungry, the kebab van comes round about six. But go easy on the chilli sauce, that stuff’s murder on your — (guts) ]
FX: TIME STORM REACHES CRESCENDO. CROSSFADE TO:
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 44
SCENE 20: EXT. RIDGEWAY
FX: TIME STORM FADES, LEAVING GENTLE WIND — OPEN FIELDS
(DAZED) Captain? W-what was that?
Time and space travel, I suppose.
I’d sooner go by TARDIS.

You and me both, Private. (LOOKING AROUND) OK, bearings. Blue sky, green grass. Might be Earth. Might not. Have to assume a hostile environment until proven otherwise. Smoke in the distance. Could be a settlement. Could be a dragon. (FRUSTRATION) Oh, this is useless! We could be anywhere in the whole of time or space.
We’re about ten miles from Swindon.
I beg your pardon?
Over there, that’s a dolmen — a Neolithic burial site. We’re on the Ridgeway Path, midway between Wantage and the M4. We came here on my Duke of Edinburgh's.
You’ve been here before? You’re certain?
Well, we might be in the Middle Ages. But I will be here at some
point in the early 20s, yeah. Funny, I’d forgotten all about that weekend. Sarah Dean brought her knitting. She was making a scarf
for Tom [Wateracre. ]
Yes, is there anything more I need to know?
FX: DISTANT HELICOPTER APPROACHING
The dolmen, it’s called [Weyland’s Smithy. They say —]
(LOOKING UP) Quiet!
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 45
Isn’t that an assault helicopter?
(SHOVING SALLY TO GROUND) Down-!
FX: STEALTH HELICOPTER SWOOPS OVER THEIR HEADS
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 46
SCENE 21: INT. FENRIC’S KEEP — HALL
FX: AS BEFORE. DOOR CREAKS OPEN, AND SHUTS
(FX: TWISTING IN CHAINS) Who’s that now-?
(SNEAKING UP FROM OFF, NERVOUS) Father? Father, is that you-?
I know that voice from somewhere, but I can’t seem to place it.
(RUSHING FORWARD) Doctor!
Don’t tell me. Byzantium? No — Persia!
It is I, Doctor. Hurmzid —
Hurmzid, Prince of Persia, that’s it! What are you doing here? (DARK) The last time I saw you, I warned you never to tangle with demons.
Wise advice. I only wish I had paid heed to it. (FX: CLANKING CHAINS) Here, let me help you with these chains. —
Yes, if only they were properly knotted I’d have been out of them long ago. But this random lash-up — it’s a disgrace!
(FX: LETTING CHAINS GO) I cannot even see how they are linked!

Never underestimate the value of a well-tied knot, Hurmzid. I once said the same to Baden-Powell, but he had a lot on his mind. Half the boys had been bewitched by sprites, the other half had turned into werewolves. It had been a very odd weekend.
Doctor, you are babbling.

Tell me, how’s your father doing? Has he released the Roman Emperor yet, or is he still using him as a footstool to get on his horse? I should have said something, but I didn’t want to invent the Geneva Convention two thousand years early.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 47
It was my father I came here in search of. You have not seen him, I suppose?
No.
I must find him.
And I’1l1 help you. But first things first. I don’t suppose you brought a hacksaw-?
I did not. Unless, of course — (FX: SWINGING RUCKSACK OFF SHOULDERS) — Ace left one in her rucksack? (FX: UNZIPS RUCKSACK)
All you'll find in there is a spare pair of tights and several cans of — (REALISATION) That’s Ace’s rucksack! You’re carrying

PEGGY: Coo-ee! Hello there, Ace, dear. Remember me-?
ACE: Oh, what?!?
SALLY: You know her?
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 89
ACE: Hex and me, we went through World War Three because of her and her Albert. Don’t let the little old lady thing fool you, she’s —
ARISTIDES: Something else. We’re not stupid, McShane.
ACE: She’s an alien god. (POINTEDLY) A minor one.
PEGGY: Mind you don’t cut yourself on that tongue of yours.
ACE: Alright, where is he?
SALLY: Her ‘Albert’, you mean?
ACE: Moloch. Her boss.
PEGGY: There’s more than one game being played here, dear.
ARISTIDES: What exactly do you mean by that?
PEGGY: Look around you, Lysandra Aristides. Over there. — And there. — Oh, and there, too. —
ACE: More bodies.
ARISTIDES: Who are they? Saxons? Vikings?
PEGGY: All sorts, dear. Someone’s been bringing whole armies here, to fight Fenric. Gathering them up from all over the place. All different times and places.
ARISTIDES: Yes, but who-?
PEGGY: Well, it’s got to be someone who’s got an old score to settle with Fenric. Someone with the means to move people about in time and space, and charismatic enough to talk them into fighting and dying on his behalf. Now, who do you think that sounds like?
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 90
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 39: EXT. PLAIN
HEX: What’s keeping Ace?
DOCTOR: The hammer will need time to recharge.
HEX: What, so she’1ll be coming the long way round?
HEX: (FX: LOW RUMBLE OF ‘THUNDER’ — ACTUALLY ONE OF SEVERAL ELDER GODS MATERIALISING IN THE SKY, BROUGHT BY A TIME STORM, BUT IT’LL
SOUND: LIKE DISTANT THUNDER HERE)
DOCTOR: Something in the air. A storm on the way. Come along, Mr Hex. We'll be needing that shield.
HEX: Oh, right. (HEFTING SHIELD) Well, where are going?
DOCTOR: The TARDIS.
HEX: Yeah, like Fenric’s really going to let you quit this game of yours before it’s finished.
DOCTOR: I don’t suppose he will. But a Time Lord’s TARDIS is his castle.
HEX: Chess again. So you’re making a play?
DOCTOR: No. But I’d like to see the board from another perspective.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 91
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 40: INT. FENRIC’S KEEP — HALL
FENRIC: (MURMURED) Ancient One. Come to me.
ANCIENT ONE: My master. You have... returned.
FENRIC: Returned, yes, to find the Doctor gone!
ANCIENT ONE: It was the woman. “Ace”. She had... great faith.
FENRIC: So, my opponent has had a free hand, in my absence. But I see from the board that there are few plays left open to him. There, by his castle, the Queen that thinks she’s a Knight, the Knight that thinks she’s a Bishop... and, yes, a pawn broken free from the [front rank] — (BREAKS OFF)
ANCIENT ONE: Master? What troubles you?
FENRIC: The board is not as it was. One of Black’s pawns has been taken! The Prince of Persia, I believe...?
ANCIENT ONE: Once, he was my son.
FENRIC: And?
ANCIENT ONE: The ties between a father and his son are not easily severed.
FENRIC: I would not know. I have no children. Only wolves.
ANCIENT ONE: With his death, I believed that I would be absolved of my sins. But I am as cursed as I ever was.
FENRIC: So, you presumed to play my hand for me, Ancient One?
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 92
ANCIENT ONE: I would weep, had I tear ducts in this corruption of a body.
FENRIC: Pity yourself all you like. The game has no pity. (DECISIVELY) Summon the Haemovores. I will need more pawns to sacrifice. Perhaps I will sacrifice you too, my last Bishop. If you’re good.
ANCIENT ONE: Then... the game nears its end?
FENRIC: One piece is shielded from me still. But I see now that it can only be hidden behind another. (FX: MOVING CHESSPIECE) White rook to E7!
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 93
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 41: EXT. PLAIN — BY STREAM
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: STREAM OFF. MORE LOW ‘THUNDER’ ... DISGUISING THE GRINDING ‘CHUDD!’ OF FENRIC’S CASTLE MOVING INTO POSITION, OFF)
HEX: (FX: WALKING WITH DOCTOR) More thunder.
DOCTOR: (WALKING) If that’s what it is. What a time to be caught without an umbrella. I left a lovely one on the bridge at Arnhem. A black Fulton minister. I couldn’t go back for it, the Germans had us hemmed in on three [sides. ]
HEX: (FX: WALKING INTO STREAM — SPLASHING) Oh, man! Gonna be the death of me trainers. — (REALISATION) Hang about, this is the stream we
HEX: followed before.
DOCTOR: Then the TARDIS is close by?
HEX: (SCRAMBLING FORWARD) Just over this ridge, I think — (AT TOP) Oh hell.
DOCTOR: (FOLLOWING) What is it? Let me see. — Ah.
HEX: There’s the TARDIS alright. But look what’s beside it!
DOCTOR: Yes, Fenric has moved his castle.
FENRIC: (CALLING, WELL OFF) Doctor! Where are you...? Doctor!!!
HEX: Oh, and there he is. The original green-eyed monster.
DOCTOR: (DECISIVELY) Wait here, Mr Hex.
HEX: You’re not gonna go to him-?!
DOCTOR: (MOVING OFF) Stay out of sight. Protect the shield.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 94
FENRIC: (CALLING YOU) I know you’re close by, Doctor. I’m the big bad wolf, I can smell you...!
DOCTOR: (APPROACHING FROM OFF) Very clever, Fenric, the way you move your pieces around the board.
FENRIC: It’s easy enough. All the matter, all the mass of the universe to come is mine to command here.
DOCTOR: Like tins on a supermarket shelf. Moving fresh food to the back so the older items can be sold first.
FENRIC: If you must. So: how would you like me to kill you, Time Lord? Painfully, over centuries? Or painfully, over aeons? Perhaps I should make you watch as I torture your friends to death. Or perhaps I should make them torture each other? What do you think?
DOCTOR: For all your huffing and puffing, Fenric, you’re just a boy who likes pulling the wings off spiders, aren’t you?
FENRIC: The wings off — [spiders?!?] Oh, that’s very you, Doctor. Just like the good old days. Or should I say — good Old Times?
DOCTOR: I’ve had enough of this, Fenric.
FENRIC: No you haven’t. You revel in the game as much as I do. But it’s over now. Show me the shield.
DOCTOR: I don’t have it.
FENRIC: I can sense it, almost. At the edge of my perception. Out of the corner of my eye. Is it in your TARDIS? .. No. No, it isn’t. Where is it..? Where have you hidden it...?
DOCTOR: (BLUFFING) You’ve moved your pieces. I’ve moved mine.
FENRIC: You exaggerate your importance. Time Lord.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 95
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: FEROCIOUS RUMBLE OF ‘THUNDER’ — ACTUALLY ANOTHER ELDER GOD MATERIALISING IN THE SKY)
DOCTOR: That’s no ordinary thunder. What is that?
FENRIC: Look up, Doctor. Up into the broiling cosmos.
DOCTOR: Shapes in the clouds. (CALLING) The Elder Gods, I presume? Gathering for the endgame? (TO FENRIC) I should have known this was a spectator sport.
FENRIC: They know you, Time Lord. They’ve enjoyed your antics. Rushing around the bullring of the universe, like some funny little matador. But they always knew — one day you’d over-reach yourself. One day, the bull would run you through. And now, at last, that day has come!
DOCTOR: No!
FENRIC: You have lost. Time Lord. (CALLING) Rise up, my wolves! (FX:
HAEMOVORE: MOANING FROM ALL DIRECTIONS — A MASS OF CREATURES EMERGING FROM ALL AROUND. SOME BREAKING THE SOIL, LIKE ZOMBIES) Rise up from the mists, and the soil! Sweep the Doctor and his friends from the board!
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 96
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 42: EXT. BATTLEFIELD
SALLY: What is that?
ARISTIDES: Just thunder.
PEGGY: Oh no. Not thunder, my pet. That’s the Old Gods gathering. The game must be nearing its end.
ACE: That can’t be good.
PEGGY: Fenric will be making his play. Bringing his legions forward.
ACE: Legions-?
ARISTIDES: So what are you saying? There’s a big push coming-?
SALLY: Captain, we should get under cover. Defend our position.
ARISTIDES: You’re right. Morgan, McShane — back to the Smithy!
PEGGY: The Smithy, dear? The Smithy’s gone.
ARISTIDES: Gone? But it was just [here —]
PEGGY: Well, it’s not there now. (TEASING) Perhaps someone’s moved it?
ARISTIDES: ‘Someone’? Who?
SALLY: The Doctor?
ACE: She’s winding you up. It isn’t him. It can’t be.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 97
PEGGY: Would you care to test that, Ace? Place your faith in him, to repel the hordes of Fenric’s wolves?
ARISTIDES: Oh, so it’s ‘hordes’ now.
SALLY: Captain? What do we do?
PEGGY: If I were you, dear — I’d dig out what you can. There’s weapons all over the battlefield, if you look. Bits and bobs left here for the armies sent to fight Fenric.
ACE: Saxon armies-?
PEGGY: Saxon armies. Roman armies. All sorts of armies.
ARISTIDES: These Elder Gods. What’s wrong with a plain old-fashioned chessboard?
ACE: Back in Perivale, I had this mate, Midge. Got into ‘Dungeons & Dragons’ one summer, spent all his time indoors painting up little lead orcs and goblins. Thing was, you didn’t need the little lead figures to play the game. He just reckoned they made it more realistic.
PEGGY: (FX: DIGGING IN MUD, WITH FINGERS) Go on. Have a good root about, all of you. (FX: SLOOP AS SHE PRODUCES SOMETHING FROM THE MUD) Look, here’s something!
ACE: What is it?
PEGGY: A null field anti-cannon. It might look like a glittery tube with a wind chime for sights, but actually —
ACE: Gordon Bennett!
SALLY: (ASIDE) Captain — are we missing something here?
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 98
ARISTIDES: Like what?
SALLY: Roman armies? With alien guns?
ARISTIDES: Your point being...?
SALLY: Who made all these weapons? What for?
ARISTIDES: You heard the old woman. To fight Fenric. And that’s what we’re doing. Fighting Fenric.
SALLY: I know. It’s just — I think someone else is, too.
ACE: (SLIGHTLY OFF) Oi! Why don’t you stop gossiping, you two, and start getting your hands dirty?!
PEGGY: (FURTHER OFF STILL) Look, there’s all sorts over here! .. Mind the landmines, though. Beastly things, they should be banned.
ARISTIDES: You heard them, Morgan.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 99
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 43: EXT. PLAIN — BY STREAM
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: AS BEFORE — SEETHING MASS OF GROANING HAEMOVORES ADVANCING STEADILY ON THE DOCTOR, THROUGH: )
FENRIC: (CALLING, FROM BEHIND LINE OF HAEMOVORES) Onward, my legions! Free will to the pawn who takes the Time Lord down! (TO DOCTOR) Make your play, Doctor. If you have one.
DOCTOR: (BACKING AWAY) Oh, I’m always thinking one step ahead, Fenric. Shouldn’t you know that by now?
HEX: (OFF) Doctor! Doctor!!!
DOCTOR: I told you — stay back!
HEX: (OFF) There’s more of them this way, coming up from the water!
DOCTOR: Try not to panic!
FENRIC: Who are you talking to? Doctor?
DOCTOR: No-one! Myself!
FENRIC: . The shield, of course. It’s there with you, isn’t it? I can’t see it, that’s all.
HEX: (WITH THE DOCTOR) Doctor, do something!
DOCTOR: Any second now, Hex. I think. (UNCERTAIN) I hope.
FENRIC: Eh? Your TARDIS, Time Lord. It just —
DOCTOR: (BLUFFING) Just, er, moving one of the tins around the supermarket shelf?
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 100
HEX: (TO DOCTOR) How’d you do that?
FENRIC: You cannot! You do not have the power! .. Oh, but this is not your play, is it?
DOCTOR: (FX: KEY IN DOOR, OPENS) Into the TARDIS, Hex! Hurry!
HEX: (ENTERING) You don’t have to tell me —
FENRIC: You know what this means, don’t you?
DOCTOR: Make your play, Fenric. If you have one.
FENRIC: Your castle is not your own, Time Lord! Your castle is not your own!
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 101
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 44: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
HEX: Come on, Doctor, how did you do it? Summon the TARDIS like that?
DOCTOR: I didn’t.
HEX: Fenric’s face. Thought he was gonna explode with — (DOUBLE TAKE) You didn’t?
DOCTOR: Any more than I set its next destination.
HEX: Doctor, you’re scaring me. Actually scaring me.
DOCTOR: All this time I thought I was playing Fenric at some vast game of chess, played out on a cosmic level. I thought I was the black king, and he was the white.
HEX: You were Black-? But Black’s — [evil]
DOCTOR: Mr Hex. Try looking beyond your literal ideas about good and evil!
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 102
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 45: EXT. BATTLEFIELD
PEGGY: I do believe the gods are all assembled.
ARISTIDES: Which means-?
ACE: It’s showtime. (FX: KA-CHUNK OF WEAPON) Lock and load, everyone.
SALLY: (FX: KA-CHUNK) You don’t have to tell me.
ARISTIDES: She doesn’t, no. I do, Private! (FX: KA-CHUNK)
SALLY: Sorry, [Ma’am. ]
PEGGY: Ah, and there he is. There’s old Fenric.
FENRIC: (ALOUD) The game is nearly run. Our forces are committed. This
FENRIC: thing must be played to its end.
FENRIC: (FX: MULTIPLE THUNDERCLAPS — LIKE THE APPLAUSE OF THE GODS. CROSS
BACK TO: )
SALLY: That’s not thunder, it’s more like —
PEGGY: The gods applaud.
ARISTIDES: Where does he think he is? Wembley Stadium?
ACE: Yeah, they’1ll be throwing their knickers at him next.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 103
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 46: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
HEX: I don’t get this. Any of this.
DOCTOR: In my arrogance, I believed myself to be Fenric’s opposite. His equal. But all this time, I’ve been just another piece on the board. Played for a fool.
HEX: By Fenric?
DOCTOR: By his opponent. (FX: TIME ROTOR GRINDS TO A HALT) We’ve arrived. Bring the shield.
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 104
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 47: EXT. RIDGEWAY/WEYLAND’S SMITHY
HEX: Oh. I was expecting — I dunno, a dungeon or something.
DOCTOR: We’re on the Ridgeway Path. An ancient route through the west of England. Early in the Middle Ages, I'd say.
HEX: Pretty. (SPOTTING SOMETHING ON THE DISTANCE) Hey, on the far hill. One of those big chalk horses.
DOCTOR: A white knight, watching over the enemy camp.
HEX: You what?
DOCTOR: Everything’s symbolic.
HEX: Hang about — what’s that sound? —
DOCTOR: To your left, Mr Hex. Follow me.
HEX: Oh. Yeah. There’s smoke, coming out of that — I dunno, cave?
DOCTOR: It’s a dolmen, a Neolithic burial site. Legend calls it Weyland’s Smithy.
HEX: Weyland? Like Weyland’s Shield?
DOCTOR: Weyland was the blacksmith of the gods. They say that if your horse needed shoeing, you could tie it here, and bury a coin, and the job would be done by the morning. (FX: THEY STOP) (CALLING) Hello? Anyone home?
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 105
WEYLAND: (SLIGHTLY OFF) (GRUFF) Do you something, stranger?
HEX: (TO DOCTOR) That’s a relief, it’s just a man. I was expecting a monster or something.
DOCTOR: (APPROACHING WEYLAND) We’ve not met. But we’re not strangers, I think.
WEYLAND: Didn’t hear you arrive. Been busy, at my forge.
HEX: His what?
DOCTOR: Hex, may I introduce Weyland, a blacksmith. (DARK) The. Black. Smith.
HEX: (REALISATION) Oh no.
WEYLAND: Everything’s symbolic. “Hex”.
DOCTOR: Weyland — or Volund, in the original Norse. Fenric’s opponent. A maker of weapons. Tools for gods to fight other gods.
HEX: The man who made the shield!
WEYLAND: “Man”, you say. (FX: PIERCING THROB AS WEYLAND BEGINS TO MANIFEST HIMSELF IN HIS NATURAL FORM, THROUGH:) (EFFORT) Little mortal, I
WEYLAND: am so much more than a man.
HEX: What’s he doing? What’s happening?
DOCTOR: Don’t look at him, Hex.
HEX: His angles are all wrong. His shape, it doesn’t make sense!
DOCTOR: His natural form. He’s an elder being, from the dark places beyond your dimension. — I said, look away!
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 106
HEX: There are — colours in him. Colours like I’ve never seen.
WEYLAND: (FX: HORRIFIC VOICE DISTORT) Look at me. Hex. Am I not mighty? Am I not your god?!?
DOCTOR: Close your eyes, Hex! Your consciousness isn’t able to take him in, not like this! It’1ll snap!
HEX: (LOSING IT) But he is, Doctor. He is mighty. He is my god!
DOCTOR: Please, Hex! You’1l go mad!
WEYLAND: END OF PART THREE
DOCTOR WHO: GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 107

elements.text: PART FOUR
Close your eyes, Hex! Your consciousness isn’t able to take him in, not like this! It’ll snap!
(LOSING IT) But he is, Doctor. He is mighty. He is my god!
Please, Hex! You’ll go mad!
D) (LAUGHS
SCENE CONTINUES:
SCENE 48: EXT. WEYLAND’S SMITHY [CONTINUED]
Weyland — Volund — whoever you are, I demand you revert to human form!
(D) You? A single grain of sand on a beach, begging a mighty ocean to retreat. You are nothing.
No. I’m the Doctor. And that was your one warning!
So many, many colours...
FX: PIERCING THROB DROPS AS WEYLAND RETURNS TO HUMAN FORM
Thank you.
The shield still has its part to play. (FX: SNAPS FINGERS) You.
(DULLY) My Lord Weyland-?
The endgame is near. Return to my castle, the TARDIS. The door will be open. Wait for me there.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 108
As you command. (WALKS)
“Your” TARDIS, Weyland? You will never be master of my TARDIS.
I already am. Don’t you realise how long this game has been running?
Since Scutari. Since Hex sustained a mortal wound that you stepped in to cure.
He is my creature. Without my protection, he would have long since bled to death.
Hex is not your pawn! He is a human being!
No. He is just another weapon from the fires of my Forge.
Your Forge? (UNCERTAIN) The Forge was Nimrod’s creation. Not yours.
Ohh, I was always there, Time Lord. Unseen. Unnoticed. Unacknowledged.
I don’t believe you.

A long game, yes. Laying my tricks and traps, filling your TARDIS with my Black agents. Sergeant Aristides, another product of the Forge. Private Morgan, whose parents died in a volley of bullets made here, by me.
That isn’t possible-!
Perhaps you think they just fell into your path? Like Dorothy McShane?
What’s Ace got to do with it?
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 109
Look out on the hillside, Doctor. The chalk horse?
Fenric’s White Knight. So-?
He was always watching me; do you think I was never watching him? As far back as.. what was the name of it..? ‘Perivale’, yes.
Perivale-?
How was it you once described it? “An idyllic place, with lush green fields, [and] —”
. and a village blacksmith. I remember.
Your friends were always mine, like Dorothy McShane once belonged to my opponent. Poor Doctor. So long now, you’ve been the plaything of the gods. But your part in the game is over. (BEGINS
OFF)
Wait — where are you going?
(WALKING) I depart for the battlefield.
(CALLING AFTER HIM) And what about me? What will you do with me?

(AT TARDIS DOOR) Why — nothing, Doctor. But if you wait here a thousand years or so, you’ll have a fine view of the end of this world at the hands of my agents. (FX: TARDIS DOOR SLAMS; IT DEMATERIALISES IN A TIME STORM)
Weyland, wait! You can’t just leave me [here!] (BEAT; THE TARDIS
GONE) (TO SELF) .. Oh. You can.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 110
SCENE 49: EXT. BATTLEFIELD
(CALLING) Reveal yourself, my opponent! Reveal yourself, I say!
FX: CROSS BACK TO:
Whoever he’s expecting, looks like a no-show —
(FX: AND THEN, ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE SOUND FIELD TO FENRIC, THE TARDIS VWORPS INTO EXISTENCE. MORE THUNDERING APPROVAL)
The TARDIS.
It can’t be-!
Face it, McShane. The old woman was right about the Doctor.
Oh, Peggy was only teasing you, ducks. (UNCERTAIN) Unless... no. No, surely not...
FX: CROSS TO: TARDIS DOOR OPENS... AND WEYLAND STEPS OUT
Fenric. I am ready!
FX: CROSS BACK TO:
That’s not the Doctor. That’s — I don’t know who that is!
Freddie Mercury, to judge by the ‘tache. Guess this is Wembley, after all.
That’s Volund, girl. Mighty Volund.
Who’s ‘Volund’ when he’s at home?
It’s Weyland. Don’t you see? ‘Volund’ was another name for Weyland!
As in Weyland’s Shield?
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 111
Exactly! Weyland was the blacksmith of the gods, you see —
Yes, we’ve established that. — Look, there’s Schofield. Coming out of the TARDIS!
FX: CROSS TO:
(CALLING) We play the game again, Volund. But — where is the shield?
FX: CROSS TO:
(CALLING) Safe from you! Don’t you fear — I’1ll keep to our bargain, Fenric. Win the game, and the shield is yours!
FX: CROSS TO:
I don’t get it. Hex is holding the shield. Why can’t Fenric see him-?
What I don’t get is, why’s Hex just standing there-? (CALLING) Hex. H— (MUFFLED BY ARISTIDES)
(HISSED) Shut up, McShane!
(MUFFLED SHOUT) [Hex!!!]
FX: CROSS TO:
(CALLING) Ah. I see — your knight, your bishop, your pawn... oh yes, and the troublesome piece that never seems to know which side
it’s on. Is that all you have to play with, Volund?
FX: CROSS TO:
(CALLING) There’s more, Fenric. Much more. Make your play!
FX: CROSS TO:
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 112
(CALLING) (FX: TIME STORM WHIPPING UP THROUGH...) Men of the Dane, men of ancient bloodgilt, Fenrir [sic] calls you to honour the debt you left unpaid...
FX: CROSS TO:
What’s he saying?
I’d’ve thought that was obvious, dear.
(BREAKING FREE OF ARISTIDES) Get off me, Lysandra! .. He’s summoning his wolves. Summoning an army!
FX: CROSS TO:
(CALLING) I will receive payment in your souls, and your place in Hell will be judged worthy!
(FX: TIME STORM PEAKS — AND A GROANING MASS OF HAEMOVORES IS SUDDENLY IN PLACE, BESIDE HIM. CROSS TO: )
A few thousand zombie Vikings. I’d call that ‘game over’.
FX: CROSS TO WEYLAND SUMMONING UP HIS ARMY IN TIME STORM:
(CALLING) Come to me, Men of Mercia. Men of Wessex, heed my call!
(SIGHING, SCHOOLGIRL CRUSH) I suppose — he does look a little like Freddie Mercury when he puffs his chest out like that.
How do you know Freddie Mercury?
I spent a little time on Earth, dear. Everyone likes a spot of Queen, don’t they? ‘We Will Rock You’, that’s my favourite.
(FX: TIME STORM PEAKS — AND A GROANING MASS OF ZOMBIE SAXONS IS SUDDENLY IN PLACE, BESIDE WEYLAND)
And in the black corner — zombie Saxons.
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 113
Vikings... versus Saxons. And us in the middle. What do we do now, ‘Captain’?
How should I know?
The Doctor would know.
Yes, well — he’s not here, is he? We can’t ask him.
Oh, but we can. Because I’ve still got Prince Hurmzid’s hammer. And going by the shine on it — it’s nicely charged up now. (FX:
HAMMER ON FLOOR) The Doctor! (FX: TIME STORM WHIPS UP
HER, THROUGH: )
Oh, nice. What are we supposed to do in the meantime?
(FADING AWAY) Just — find a foxhole and wait, Lysandra!
FX: AND SHE’S GONE. CROSS TO:
(CALLING) You call this rabble of yours an army, Volund? My wolves will gain little sustenance from such... thin blood.
FX: CROSS TO:
(CALLING) Get on with it, Fenric!
FX: CROSS TO:
(CALLING) As you wish. (TO HAEMOVORES) Advance!
FX: HAEMOVORES CHARGE AT SAXONS, SHRIEKING, GROANING. CROSS TO:
(CALLING) At them, Men of Mercia! Let battle be joined!
(FX: ROARING, THE SAXONS CHARGE TO MEET THE HAEMOVORES.
‘APPLAUSE’. LIGHTNING, PERHAPS, AS THE GODS ‘CHEER’ ?)
GODS AND MONSTERS by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 114
SCENE 50: EXT./INT. WEYLAND’S SMITHY
(FX: BIRDSONG AS BEFORE. REPEATED TAPPING OF HAMMER ON ANVIL OFF,
INSIDE SMITHY. TIME STORM FLASH AS ACE MATERIALISES OUTSIDE)
Well, at least it’s not Perivale. (CALLING) Professor!
FX: HAMMER STOPS
(CREEPING FORWARD) Professor...?
(FX: FLIPPING UP METAL VISOR/FACEPLATE ) Ace. There you are!
Where’ve you been? And what’s with the faceplate, and the gauntlets?
Ah. Those. I’ve been doing a spot of metalwork. Come in, come in. —
FX: FOLLOW THE DOCTOR AND ACE INSIDE SMITHY
